facts.text: Appellant (landlord) made application under S. 13 of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 for eviction of respondent (tenant) alleging non-payment of rent for premises from October 1, 1959 to June 30, 1961. Rent was Rs. 32/8/- plus water connection charges Rs. 2/8/-

On first date of hearing, tenant tendered Rs. 292/8/- as rent from October 1, 1960 to June 30, 1961, Rs. 7/- as interest, and Rs. 25/- as costs. Amounts accepted by landlord without prejudice to claim for earlier period

Tenant made two deposits in Court of Senior Sub-Judge, Ludhiana under s. 31 of East Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act, 1934: Rs. 210/- on December 23, 1959 and Rs. 210/- on July 18, 1960. Deposits claimed as valid tender of rent
Deposits under s. 31 were not only of arrears of rent but prospectively for some future period for which rent was not then due
Rent Controller held tenant not in default. Order affirmed by Appellate Authority and Punjab High Court on March 18, 1964 in Civil Revision No. 750 of 1962
High Court followed earlier decision in Mam Chand v. Chhotu Ram reported in 1 L.R. 1964 1 Pb. 626
Before Supreme Court hearing, respondent objected to special leave alleging inaccurate statements in petition regarding issues before lower courts
Supreme Court rejected respondent's objection (C.M.P. No. 64 of 1969) holding no false averment in special leave petition

legal_issues.text: Whether deposit under s. 31 of the East Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act, 1934 constitutes a valid tender or payment of rent under s. 13 of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 so as to save tenant from eviction

petitioner_arguments.text: Deposit under s. 31 of Relief of Indebtedness Act is not a valid tender under s. 13 of Urban Rent Restriction Act. Challenged correctness of High Court decision and earlier decision in Mam Chand v. Chhotu Ram
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 13 East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949

respondent_arguments.text: Deposit under s. 31 of Relief of Indebtedness Act was valid tender of rent under s. 13 of Urban Rent Restriction Act
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S. 31 East Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act, 1934; S. 13 East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949; Mam Chand v. Chhotu Ram

respondent_arguments.text: Special leave should not be granted due to inaccurate, untrue and misleading statements in petition for special leave regarding issues before lower courts
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Hari Narain v. Badri Das; Rajabhai Abdul Rehman Munshi v. Vasudev Dhanjibhai Mody

court_reasoning.text: S. 13 of Urban Rent Restriction Act provides only one mode for tenant to save eviction: tender full arrears of rent, interest and costs on first hearing before Rent Controller. No other deposit procedure provided in the Act
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act does not lay down any other procedure under which money can be deposited with any Government Authority

court_reasoning.text: S. 31 of Relief of Indebtedness Act intended for debtors-creditors relations involving interest; not for landlords-tenants where no interest ordinarily payable. Deposit stops interest from running, which is irrelevant for rent
court_reasoning.key_observation: Phrase 'any person who owes money' must be read in context of Act as whole, covering cases with interest agreements

court_reasoning.text: Senior Sub-Judge Court not intended as clearing house for rent. Partial deposits allowed under s. 31 cannot be valid tender for rent. Deposits here included future rent, contrary to s. 19 read with s. 6 of Rent Act prohibiting advance rent recovery
court_reasoning.key_observation: Landlords not required to check Senior Sub-Judge Court for tenant deposits

court_reasoning.text: High Court misunderstood s. 31; Division Bench view contrary to two single Judge decisions of same court preferring narrower interpretation
court_reasoning.key_observation: Single Judges' decisions to be preferred

court_reasoning.text: No gross misstatement in special leave petition; only one issue before all courts
court_reasoning.key_observation: Objection not sustainable unlike Hari Narain and Rajabhai cases

holdings.text: Deposit under s. 31 of East Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act, 1934 does not constitute valid payment or tender under s. 13 of East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 and does not save tenant from eviction consequences of default

precedents_cited.relevance: Followed by High Court Division Bench but held incorrect; extended view of s. 31 deposit
Cited by respondent for denying special leave due to misstatements; distinguished as no gross misstatement here

precedents_cited.case_name: Rajabhai Abdul Rehman Munshi v. Vasudev Dhanjibhai Mody
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by respondent for denying special leave due to misstatements; distinguished

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs eviction for non-payment of rent; only specific tender on first hearing saves tenant; prohibits advance rent recovery

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act, 1934
statutes_cited.relevance: Allows deposit to stop interest in debtor-creditor relations; not applicable to landlord-tenant rent payments

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned in proviso to S. 13 of 1949 Act

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, judgment of Punjab High Court set aside, eviction of tenant ordered with three months time to vacate the premises. Costs throughout borne by respondent.
outcome.relief_granted: Eviction of tenant from premises; three months to vacate

key_quotes.text: "The Act does not lay down any other procedure under which money can be deposited with any Government Authority. Such provisions are to be found in other Rent Control Acts but are missing in this Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains strict interpretation of s. 13 tender requirement

key_quotes.text: "No interest is agreed to be paid by tenants, at any rate, not ordinarily, and, therefore, the section cannot be said to cover a case between a landlord and a tenant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key reason why s. 31 Relief Act inapplicable to rent

key_quotes.text: "It could not have been intended that all tenants who may be disinclined to pay rent to their landlords should be enabled to deposit it in the Court of a Senior Sub-Judge making the Senior Sub-Judge, a kind of a Rent Collector for all landlords."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects broad application of s. 31 to rent disputes
